text: hi I'm Elise welcome to my cupcake
addiction on today's episode I'm going
to show you how to make this stunning
ombre layer princess cake and our
beautiful princess of choice today is
none other than the lovely Aurora from
the Sleeping Beauty movie I'm making
this cake today to celebrate the
Australian release of Sleeping Beauty on
DVD and blu-ray and the guys over at
Disney have been super nice and they've
offered up some DVDs and also some of
those gorgeous Aurora princess dolls to
give away I will leave a link down below
telling you how you can get your hands
on one of those great prize packs let's
get started with today's beautiful
princess cake to make your aurora cake
of course you're going to need an Aurora
doll when you're choosing this make sure
you get the one with the plastic bodice
not any sort of fabric on the top half
of her body I've got an open round
piping tip and a circle cutter a pair of
scissors some of my perfectly pipeable
buttercream frosting in both white and
also pink so I will link to that recipe
in the description box below I've got
some pink and some white food coloring
I've got a disposable piping bag a
spatula and offset spatula and a bread
knife off to the side I have a metal
bowl which I'm just going to be using to
bake a round piece of cake in and I've
also got an 8-inch cake tin so the bowl
size that I've chosen sort of fits
really nicely on that 8-inch cake tin
they're about the same size I've got a
12 inch cake board and then just a
thinner cardboard 8 inch cake board I'm
going with a sparkly bling finish on my
cake board so if you want to achieve
this you'll also need a piece of glitter
scrapbooking paper from your local craft
store of course you'll need some cake so
I've got a triple batch of the cupcake
addiction vanilla cake recipe from my
recipe ebook which I will link to down
below otherwise you can use your
favourite cake mix and I'm taking the
equivalent of about a fifth so for me
that's about three scoops I'm going to
add in some of this bright white food
coloring because I'm using a yellow cake
mix that whites just going to go through
and make a really nice light color for
the top layer of my cake now I've
greased and floured that bowl so butter
or oil and then flour and then I'm just
scooping that fifth of the mixture in
and I'm going to bake that physically in
the bowl I
found the bowl took a little bit longer
to bake than the tin about 20 minutes or
so and you'll see I've only filled that
to a third of the way up the bowl off
into the oven and then on to some of our
pink layers so I divided my mixture into
five and then each of these other four
layers I've added different amounts of
food coloring I started with half a drop
and then I doubled it to one drop
doubled it to two drops and doubled it
to four drops that's the way I achieve a
beautiful ombre finish stir that color
through and then you want to scoop it
into a lined greased baking tin so I've
lined my with some baking paper and
because my mix is quite thick I'm using
my spatula just to level it all so it's
really nice and smooth on top I'm going
to pop that into a moderate oven and
it's going to take about 15 to 20
minutes to cook because it's only about
a third of the way full again so they're
not very thick layers you want to repeat
this with your four different shades of
ombre just using that method of doubling
the amount of food color you put in each
time while they're baking we can do a
little bit of crafting so I've got my
board and my scrapbooking paper and some
scissors and glue and just a marker I'm
just going to flip that paper over and
just trace around the shape of my board
with the marker and then I'm cutting it
out and I'm going to just glue it to the
board when you're gluing this to the
board make sure that you've got the glue
all the way to the very outside edges of
your board once it's nicely positioned
take your other cake board or a book or
something and just press down on it
making sure that you keep it relatively
centered on the board and then you want
to dry that board upside down under
something like a phone book or under
something a little bit heavy so that it
dries really really nice and flat now
your cake should be out of the oven and
they should be completely cool before
you start carving them don't try to
carve these warm or they're going to
fall apart so I'm just using a serrated
edge knife here and you'll see I'm
turning the cake that helps me to get a
really even cut and I'm also going to
cut two of my layers side-by-side so
that they're all the same height this is
really important for a layer cake
because it gives you a really neat
finish look at the differentiation that
we've got in colors there once you've
turned to where the tops flip the cakes
over and just very very carefully trim
away the bottoms they're going to be a
little bit sort of crusty or crunchy
where they've baked be really careful
doing this because you don't want to
crack the cake and take off any dark
edges that you can see now for the
stacking take some the buttercream
frosting and pop it on that 8-inch board
that you
soon for the 8-inch cakes it's going to
act like a bit of a glue and then take
your darkest pink colored layer we're
going to start dark at the bottom to
light at the top place it onto the board
and then we want to apply a generous
layer of that buttercream frosting make
sure that you're not skimping on the
buttercream frosting because that white
breaking up the ombre is part of what
gives you a really nice finish in these
layer cakes moving on to your second
darkest color and you're going to repeat
this process all the way up the cake and
do you've got your four colored layers
stacked you'll see I'm trying to keep
the amount of buttercream that I'm
putting in between relatively even once
again evenness is key with ombre cakes
taking the cake you baked in your bowl
you just want to trim the rounded dome
top of it so you've got a nice flat top
flip it over and then cut it in half
which is going to give us like sort of
two white layers to go on top but it's
once again keeping the evenness of the
layers all the same throughout this cake
so place those two on apply your
buttercream and your cake is completely
stacked and ready for the next stage now
for the next stage take your circle
cutter and you just cut a bit of a guide
circle out of just that top layer of
cake give it a twist and it should just
pull that top layer of cake out and then
you want to take a sharp knife and
you're sort of cutting down into a hole
on a bit of an angle scoop out any
excess cake but you do want that hole to
be quite narrow at the base so there's
some cake to hold aurora's feet in place
take some plastic food wrap now and you
want to wrap both her head with her hair
and also her legs wrap her legs nice and
tightly and make sure that plastic wrap
comes all the way up over her hips and
covers her hip joints slightly over her
waistband we're wrapping her hair so
that it doesn't go into our cake at all
and it doesn't get frosting in it pop
her straight down into the cake and then
you just want to take your piping bag
with a little bit of frosting and just
sub froster in the frosting is going to
help to hold her in place nice and
steady once you're happy with your
Aurora placement take your large
serrated edge knife and you can see I'm
cutting down on an angle and I'm just
starting to make the basic shape of that
cake now I'm actually going to go round
and make the shape a little bit more
defined so I'm cutting down a little
rough to begin with and just taking off
all of those outer layers of the cake so
you shouldn't see any brown crusty edges
you can see I've still got a few Sankar
down with a smaller serrated edge knife
now and I'm making sure that I can't see
any of those Brown edges any brown in
your cake is going to show up when you
cut your ombre layers and you don't want
that
the smaller serrated edge knife is great
to get that really nice neat even finish
and once you're happy with your shape
you just want to clean up your cake
board and get ready for frosting now for
frosting we're going to take some pink
buttercream frosting and you can see I'm
working my spatula back and forward into
the cake I'm applying quite a bit of
pressure here because I'm actually
creating a crumb coat it's a really thin
thin coat of frosting that catches all
of the crumbs and seals that cake which
also helps for freshness and moisture
once my cakes coated in frosting I'm
using my offset spatula just to scrape
off any excess so we're not over
frosting this cake I filled my piping
bag with that pink buttercream frosting
and now we're going to frost up by just
piping a large dot and then using the
side of your piping tip or the edge of
your piping tip to drag that dot in an
upwards direction this forms like a
layered petal technique so you just want
a dot and then you want to drag dot and
then drag and repeat that all the way
around your cake you're going to lose
and layer these over the top of each
other so as I'm doing my second layer
it's actually going about a centimeter
or so over that bottom layer which gives
us that sort of ruffles or petaled
layered effect of the skirt I love this
technique for frosting particularly with
these princess dresses I think it's
really simple and it's so effective and
nobody can believe how easy is repeat
that process all the way around your
cake and once you start to get up closer
to her waist you want to come in nice
and tight but you want to get all the
way in without making too much of a mess
so I just took a knife here and just
sort of scoop the frosting up around her
waist a little bit and then just use
your finger to sort of neaten it off so
that she's got a really nice neat for us
to Dinn waistband to add that little bit
of sparkle to this cake we're using our
glittered cake board so to stick her
down just take a blob of that
buttercream frosting pop it on the board
and then you want to use your knife to
just pry that eighth inch cake board up
off your bench or your work surface in
my case off the other cake board that
I'm using just place your hands under
NEADS gently move Arora across into the
center of your cake board and pop her
down your Princess Aurora cake is now
complete and any little princess is
going to love this one when you cut into
it you've got that stunning layered
ombre finish and you can see how even
and neat those beautiful layers are all
that work you've gone into for the
inside of the cake has really paid off I
hope you guys have enjoyed this tutorial
make sure you check out the link down
below for that awesome Disney prize pack
and as always thanks very much for
watching
